title: Everything You Need to Know About the "Day Without Immigrants" Protests Happening Today
text:
In protest of President Donald Trump’s Muslim ban (which is currently on hold after a federal appeals court halted its enforcement) and his plan to build a wall on the Mexican border, thousands of restaurants and businesses across the country will close Thursday. The “Day Without Immigrants” is meant to demonstrate how integral immigrants are to American businesses.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The movement, which originated in D.C., extends further than just closing shop for the day, the New York Times reports. Organizers ask anyone foreign-born living in the U.S. regardless of his or her legal status to also not shop to further show how vital immigrant consumer spending is to the country. According to USA Today , immigrants and children of immigrants are also encouraged to skip school as part of the demonstration.
Sign posted on door at Zavino at 13th and Sansom. Restaurant will be closed today for 'Day without Immigrants'. pic.twitter.com/VpuPQIXpRW
— Katherine Scott (@KScott6abc) February 16, 2017 It’s unclear how the idea for the Day Without Immigrants began, but the movement spread nationwide through social media and local activist groups. Restaurants in New York City, Chicago, L.A., Philadelphia, Austin, Boston, and many more are closing as well.
The most high-profile closures may be Jose Andres’s: the Spanish-born celebrity chef is currently mid-lawsuit with Donald Trump for pulling out of a restaurant deal for Trump’s D.C. hotel. Five of Andres’s restaurants will be closed. “We are all one," he told USA Today. "We should not be fighting among each other, we should all be working together to keep moving the country forward.”
In support of our people & #ADayWithoutImmigrants Thurs 2/16 we will not open @jaleo DC CC MD, @zaytinya or @oyameldc #ImmigrantsFeedAmerica
— José Andrés (@chefjoseandres) February 14, 2017 Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Other chefs and business owners left the decision of whether or not to close up to their staffs . Many businesses that will remain open pledge to donate the day's profits to nonprofit organizations that benefit Latino communities.
Though NPR reports two schools will completely close for the day in D.C., school officials elsewhere are less supportive of the event. Albuquerque Public Schools issued a letter to parents earlier this week acknowledging the protest but they explained students who missed class would be issued an unexcused absence: “We respectfully ask all parents to acknowledge that students need to be in class every day to benefit from the education they are guaranteed and to avoid falling behind in school and life,” the letter read.
As of 2014, at least 42.4 million people (about 13.3 percent of the population) who lived in the United States were immigrants, per the Migration Policy Institute .
